App description says "ONLY Useful If You Are Going To The PATH Of TOTALITY!!"

FYI - Buy the $2 app ONLY if you are in the Totality, it doesn't work if you are in Partial since there is no C2 or C3.
Per Foxwood Astronomy, "It is not useful for a partial eclipse because there is nothing crucial about the timing for C1 and C4 and there is not much to announce."

The app, it appears to me, is useless unless you happen to be in the "path of totality".  It will tell you the start, mid-, and end times, the same info you can get from a local (gasp) newspaper or elsewhere.  But it won't "talk you through," as I see it, unless you also have times C2 and C3, which the app will NOT give you unless you're in, as I said, the "path of totality."  Hope that saves somebody a waste of $2.

I have a shadow snake theory maybe with testing: as the sun becomes a point source of light, heat/density differences begin to refract the light. I have heard it described that if the sun were a point source that it would twinkle like a regular star and the surface of the earth would have a lighting pattern similar to the bottom of a pool due to refraction of the uneven atmosphere. The last few moments before an eclipse may be approximating this. The parallel bands may be from the sun's light becoming a point source on one dimension but extended in the other.

I remember standing on a cliff in south Devon, UK, in '99, clear skies above us, waiting to see one of the most mystical events in nature. Then, as the event drew near and nearer, the good old British weather did its thing and blanketed the skies in cloud. We didn't get to experience the full spectacle of the total eclipse that day, but it still felt like a magical moment. The world dipped into twilight, then darkness; the singing birds in the sky retreated to their roosts and fell silent; the insects in the thickets began stirring (and biting, but that was far less magical); and the crowd of strangers, who had all forgone their usual wednesday morning rituals to stand on a grassy cliff, all shared in two minutes of awe.

I hope everyone who goes out to see the eclipse on Monday has a magical time - and that the clouds leave you alone!
